Hello,
Last two days I was trying to solve this problem. Indeed, for a fre=
e 
hydrogen/air flame Cantera calculates temperatures substantially 
lower =
than adiabatic ones (difference can be 40 K for a coarse grid). 
It happens=
 when multicomponent transport is used. For a mixture-
averaged model calcu=
lations are fine. Refining grid helps a little 
bit - difference decreases =
down to 20 K when number of grid points 
approaches 300. Further refinement=
 is impossible: Cantera has 
problems with the noise when approximating der=
ivatives. It seems for 
me that something is nor correct with calculations =
of diffusion 
terms. I did not dig in the code to check equations but it is=
 
probably due to artificial diffusion on a coarse mesh. What 
differences =
are used to approximate derivatives? Windward or central 
difference?
Best =
regards, Anatoli


--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Goodwin" <dgoodwin=
@...> wrote:
>
> Could you send me an example flame script or program that =
shows the 
problem? Thanks.
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Matei I. =
Radulescu" <matei@> wrote:
> >
> > When one computes the the free-flame str=
ucture (say H2+air at 
PTN),
> > the equilibrium temperature obtained is di=
fferent from the true
> > adiabatic flame temperature obtained via a direct=
 equilibrium
> > calculation, using the same thermo data.  The differences =
are on 
the
> > order of 10K for the example given.  Likewise, the enthalpy=
 in the
> > flame of the equilibrium products is NOT found equal to reactan=
ts
> > enthalpy, although theoretically, they should be equal.  This 
leads=
 me
> > to suspect that the non-conservative flame calculations introduces
=
> > order 1 errors in the species concentrations of the products,
> > consi=
stent with the results of the simulations!  Are these
> > *acceptable* erro=
rs???
> >
>
